block.p: Iran Sets Free 15 Captured Britons Iran released 15 British sailors and marines it seized at sea nearly two weeks ago, resolving a diplomatic impasse with what Iran's president called a ''gift'' to the British people.
American officials are reviewing a request from the Iranian government for an envoy to visit five Iranians imprisoned since an American raid in Iraq in January, a military spokesman said.

Israel Objects to U.S. Arms Deal A major arms-sale package that the Bush administration is planning to offer Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf allies to deter Iran has been delayed because of objections from Israel. Israel says that the weaponry would erode its military advantage in the region, according to senior United States officials.

U.N. Issuing Climate Report The latest United Nations assessment of the role of humans in global warming has found with ''high confidence'' that greenhouse gas emissions are at least partly responsible for a host of changes already under way.

Pelosi Meets With Syria Leader Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, said she had frank words with President Bashar al-Assad and other Syrian officials in Damascus, pressing the president over Syria's support for militant groups and insisting that his government block militants seeking to cross into Iraq.
Clashes Continue in Gaza Israeli soldiers shot dead a Palestinian who was trying to plant explosives in the Gaza Strip, Palestinian and Israeli officials said.

Inquiry on Loan Companies Reveals New Information Officials at three universities profited from the sale of shares held in a student loan company, an expanding investigation into the relationships between student loan companies and universities has found.

Obama Raises $25 Million Senator Barack Obama's presidential campaign announced raising $25 million in the first three months of the year, settling the matter of whether he could stand toe to toe with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, at least in raising money.

Bush's Picks Anger Democrats President Bush used the Congressional recess to push through his choice to be ambassador to Belgium and to fill two domestic policy positions -- provoking Democratic ire with all three appointments.

Arrests in Immigration Raid Immigration agents arrested two managers and 60 other employees of an industrial cleaning company on immigration violations and charges of identity theft in a raid at a central Illinois meatpacking plant.

Metro Areas Regain Population Several metropolitan areas that lost population or saw growth fall off when the high-tech bubble burst appear to have recovered in the year that ended July 1, new census figures show, but many coastal areas continued to hemorrhage people.

Study Finds Flaws in Screening A highly promoted and widely used computerized system for examining mammograms known as computer-aided detection, or CAD, is leading to less accuracy, not more, researchers are reporting.

City Plans to Fight AIDS By Promoting Circumcision New York City's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene is planning a campaign to encourage men at high risk of AIDS to get circumcised in light of the World Health Organization's endorsement of the procedure as an effective way to prevent the disease.

New Jersey Pension Audit Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey said he would ask independent auditors to examine state financial records to determine how severely the pension fund for state and local workers has been jeopardized by underfunding.

Racial Imbalance in Schools The overwhelmingly white and wealthy town of Greenwich, Conn., is beginning to confront the racial imbalance in its well-groomed neighborhood schools head-on for the first time, more than 50 years after the landmark desegregation ruling in Brown v. Board of Education.
Eddie Robinson The football coach at Grambling State University who helped bring racial awareness to a segregated Southern society, he was 88.

Village Claims Etruscan Chariot A mountain village in Italy is caught up in a tug of war with the Metropolitan Museum of Art over the 2,600-year-old Etruscan chariot that is a highlight of the museum's new Greek and Roman galleries.
Talks to Sell Chrysler DaimlerChrysler confirmed that it was in negotiations about a deal for the troubled American unit.
Editorials: Running for dollars; flying toward competitive skies; the consequences of corn; not an Orange Revolution.
